8/ That now leaves IL in a situation where if they do what is good for the environment AND the economy, those municipalities are contractually stuck paying off bond-holders at above market rates.  I don't envy the challenge IL regulators are grappling with.

7/ But the folks marketing the power were good sales people.  And the towns were, in general not especially sophisticated buyers.  They relied on people they trusted, who in turn took advantage of them.

6/ It was abundantly clear to anyone with expertise in the power industry that they were never going to meet the capital cost projections in their proforma - and so the towns would be paying a lot more for power than  the rosy projections they were told.
5/ (I was aware of this because I was a clean energy power developer at the time and had contacts with a lot of the folks involved.)

4/ Those contracts forced cities and towns throughout the region not only to buy the power from this facility, but also to pay a price that would provide 100% capital cost recovery, inclusive of any construction cost over-runs.  These were all negotiated and locked in early.

3/ So why not just shut it down?  Because when it was financed the developers (Peabody Energy primarily) structured a bunch of power purchase agreements ("PPAs") with municipalities throughout the midwest that were actually bond guarantees.

2/ The plant has been a boondoggle since it was built.  Over-budget, over-schedule and consistently forcing users to pay way more for electricity than they would have otherwise.  See here for details: https://rmi.org/insight/transition-opportunities-for-prairie-state-energy-campus/

1/ Backstory: IL state regulators are in the midst of negotiations to try and shut down high CO2 power sources like Prairie State.  Those negotiations are still on-going and have no federal nexus.  But their statement is made within that context.

Shutting down developments, such as Keystone XL and ANWR, is a solution in search of a problem.
Litigious environmental groups are continuing to hamstring domestic energy development at every turn, yet the facts aren‚Äôt on their side. We can develop energy cleaner and safer than anywhere else.

Myth: ANWR is classified as wilderness, so we shouldn‚Äôt drill there.
 
Fact: The 1002 area of ANWR is not designated as wilderness. In 1980, Congress set aside the 1002 area for future oil and gas drilling upon congressional approval.

Myth: We have enough oil; we don‚Äôt need more.

Fact: The U.S. is the world‚Äôs largest consumer of oil. Since we produce less domestically than we consume, we‚Äôre forced to import the rest from countries like Saudi Arabia, where we have no control over environmental regulations.

Myth: Only oil companies are interested in ANWR development.
 
Fact: Since 1980, the majority of Alaskans, 100% of Alaskan congressional delegates, 100% of Alaskan governors, and the Alaska state legislature have all been strong supporters of leasing in the 1002 area.

Myth: Drilling in ANWR would harm wildlife.
 
Fact: In 1977, oil production began at Prudhoe Bay, North America‚Äôs largest oilfield 60 miles west of ANWR. Since then,  the Central Arctic Caribou herd has grown substantially. USGS & USFWS believe this will be the case for ANWR.

Myth: All of ANWR is open to energy development.
 
Fact: ANWR is the size of Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Vermont, and New Hampshire combined. Energy development would be restricted to an area the size of 1/5 of Dulles Airport.

The Biden administration announced it will suspend all oil + gas leases in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge (ANWR). It‚Äôs concerning to see the administration give a free pass to adversaries like Russia while shutting down production here at home.

Let‚Äôs get the facts straight.
